Reviewer: Ariana Bleau Lugo

14.36.text:
my teachers began
to associate my value

19.31.text: It took me a few years to adjust,

21.52.text:
but by the time 
I reached the eighth grade,

23.99.text:
I felt like I had unlocked 
the secret to the school system.

27.61.text:
I realized that it doesn't matter
what you are learning,

34.06.text:
how to get the teachers 
to give you a good grade.

36.75.text:
So, in school, 
instead of studying the subjects,

41.18.text:
They told me 
what they wanted, I delivered,

43.57.text:
and in turn they gave me 
a great report card.

48.54.text:
right up until I graduated 
the business degree,

53.72.text:
It wasn't until graduation day
that it hit me.

60.20.text: None of the important things anyways.

64.14.text: or what I wanted to do with my life.

65.94.text:
I knew that I wanted to be happy, 
that I wanted to be fulfilled,

69.11.text: to feel like my life meant something,

71.22.text:
but other than that, 
I was completely lost.

73.84.text: I felt really alone in this search.

76.14.text:
Everyone around me appeared 
to know exactly where they were going.

79.48.text: At least that's how it seemed.

81.73.text: I soon became depressed, and overwhelmed

84.46.text:
with anxiety and the expectations
of others.

87.98.text:
So at that time, 
my dad gave me some advice.

91.84.text:
He said: "Sean, 
it doesn't matter what you do.

95.93.text: Whatever it is, just make sure

98.49.text: it's something you are passionate about.

104.45.text:
and have yet to find something 
that I'm passionate about."

108.11.text:
We hear so often how important
it is to find our passion,

110.89.text:
how it contributes to our happiness 
and our fulfillment,

113.58.text: I think many of us would agree.

115.32.text:
Then, why is it when you ask someone
what their passion is,

118.21.text:
the majority of us
have absolutely no idea?

120.38.text: How many of you know what your passion is?

123.92.text:
To search for my passion, 
I created the One Week Job project,

127.43.text:
and worked a different job
each week for a whole year.

135.95.text:
"Anybody, anywhere in the world, 
could offer me a job for one week."

139.55.text:
I asked my employers to donate 
all my wages to charity.

144.54.text:
From exploring volcanoes
as a park ranger in Hawaii,

147.23.text:
to choosing a spring fashion line
as a fashion buyer in New York,

150.49.text:
introducing songs 
as a radio DJ in Toronto,

162.62.text:
What I learned is that, in fact, 
I wasn't alone in this search.

167.14.text: It's something all of us can relate to.

169.74.text:
Whether recently graduated from college,
or later on in our career,

175.28.text:
at some point in our life, we must look 
deep inside and ask ourselves:

179.17.text: "What do I want to do with my life?"

183.75.text:
"What contribution do I want
to make to the world?"

186.78.text:
And if we don't genuinely 
explore these questions,

190.42.text: we risk looking back with regret.

193.27.text:
For instance, just last month,
I was on a plane.

195.98.text:
I sat next to Linda who was coming home
from visiting her 84-year-old mother.

200.58.text: Linda described to me how she sat there,

203.88.text: next to her mom, holding her hand,

206.20.text: but she didn't know how to comfort her.

209.21.text:
Linda's mother, 
approaching the end of her life,

212.57.text: feels that she never pursued her dreams;

220.86.text:
meant to find a well paying job
that offered security.

225.58.text:
and if you enjoyed it, 
you were one of the lucky ones.

228.83.text:
But today, that security 
is proven to be an illusion,

231.73.text:
more and more people
are seeing this moment as an opportunity.

235.79.text: There's a major shift taking place,

240.53.text:
a shift in how we as a culture 
view work and our relationship to it.

244.81.text:
No longer is our work something
that we merely endure.

247.82.text:
Our work is becoming ever more
connected to our life's work,

251.55.text:
a precious opportunity 
to share our unique gift with the world.

255.79.text: Each of my 52 weeks I'd ask my co-workers

258.32.text: what they liked most about their job.

260.29.text:
They weren't saying things 
like money, or job security.

263.09.text:
Although important, 
it wasn't the first thing they'd mention.

266.76.text:
Instead, they said things like:
"I enjoy my co-workers,"

270.17.text: "I believe that I make a difference."

275.15.text:
the Director of a preschool
in Boise, Idaho.

280.42.text:
he more resembles a football linebacker
as opposed to a child care worker.

284.98.text:
When I asked Ken what he liked most 
about his job, his eyes lit up.

288.72.text:
He said: "When I see a kid climb 
the monkey bars for the first time,

292.08.text: or tie their shoes for the first time,

294.59.text:
to know that I'm playing a part
in making that happen is incredible!"

299.65.text:
After working
on a dairy farm in week eight,

302.20.text: waking up at 5 o'clock in the morning,

304.12.text:
heading up to the barn, 
milking the cows, shoveling the manure,

307.48.text:
I couldn't understand how someone
would possibly enjoy doing this.

310.94.text:
I looked over at George, the head farmer,
and he loves it.

314.35.text:
"People need to eat," he told me.
"I feed thousands!

317.82.text:
And our organic farm 
is also healthier for the environment."

322.16.text:
The people who are the most passionate
about their work

325.43.text:
are the ones who are connected
to the meaning behind it.

329.12.text:
The actual job isn't nearly as important
as the relationship with it.

333.35.text:
They need to show up to work everyday
because they contribute their gifts,

336.96.text:
and the world is made better 
because of it.

339.34.text:
And yet, our career is only one means
of expressing our gifts,

342.57.text: one means of fulfilling our passions.

344.60.text: For some, working a job to pay the bills,

347.09.text:
allows them to explore the passions
outside of work.

350.28.text:
What's most important
is that in some aspect of our life,

353.72.text:
we give ourselves permission
to express our gifts.

357.83.text: This is when we feel truly alive.

364.18.text: "Don't ask yourself what the world needs,

367.36.text: ask yourself what makes you come alive.

372.38.text:
Because what the world needs
is people who have come alive."

382.10.text:
To embrace the interconnectedness 
of each of us.

384.56.text:
To encourage dialogue 
that allows us to approach

390.23.text:
When we embody our life's work, 
when we share our gifts,

393.06.text:
we are fulfilled, energized, 
more compassionate.

395.66.text:
In turn, we enrich ourselves, our family, 
our friends, our communities.

400.11.text:
At a time when our world
is facing major challenges

403.31.text:
at this ecological, 
economic, and social level,

406.07.text: it's no longer an act of self indulgence,

408.84.text:
it's our responsibility 
and commitment to each other.

414.95.text:
It's time to create, 
as Charles Eisenstein wrote:

419.14.text:
"The more beautiful world
our heart tells us is possible."

424.41.text: So this is my plead to your heart,

427.49.text:
to our intuitive self 
that already knows the answer

430.59.text: - that has always known the answer -

435.65.text:
What contribution 
will you offer the world?
